Scott Sears, a lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles and the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, has achieved a remarkable feat by becoming the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo and unsupported. At the age of 27, Sears completed a 702-mile trek through harsh Antarctic conditions, including 150mph winds and temperatures as low as -50 degrees Celsius.

The journey, which took 38 days, was filled with challenges such as navigating crevasses, some of which were riddled with danger due to the risk of falling into them. Sears, who is from east London, had to adapt by using skis to cross the ice instead of being roped to a teammate.

The most dangerous part of the journey was the initial section from Hercules Inlet where sea ice meets land. Sears experienced a particularly challenging day on Christmas Eve, just 38km (24 miles) from his destination, where he hit a wall and struggled to continue. However, he managed to push through with some food, music, and motivation, eventually reaching the South Pole on Christmas Day.

Sears' journey ended in a significant personal achievement, but also a significant contribution to the Gurkha Welfare Trust. He raised over £33,500 for the organization, which will be used to rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, that were destroyed in the 2015 earthquake.

Judy Murray, Andy's mother, congratulated Sears on his achievement, while Sears himself expressed his excitement and relief at having completed the journey. He is looking forward to some well-deserved rest, including a shower and food, after spending nearly six weeks alone in a tent.

The Guinness Book of Records is yet to confirm whether Sears' feat will make it into the record books, but his accomplishment is undoubtedly a testament to his resilience, determination, and physical endurance.
answers: While many people were unwrapping gifts on Christmas Day, the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray was wrapping up a 700-mile, 38-day journey through brutally cold temps and blistering winds—and, he hopes, setting a world record. Scott Sears, 27, reached the South Pole on Monday, and he says he's the youngest person ever to do so solo, though Guinness has yet to offer its final seal of approval, the BBC notes. "MERRY CHRISTMAS FROM THE SOUTH POLE! Absolutely chuffed to pieces," he wrote on his blog, where he documented his unassisted adventure, which included temperatures of minus 58 degrees and wind gusts of up to 150mph. Sears said he was so tired when he finally took a rest after his trek that he fell asleep "within about 2 minutes of my head hitting the mat." Sears, whose sister, Kim, is married to the tennis star, describes a grueling expedition with icy, crevasse-marred terrain and an isolation made worse when the "iPod poltergeist" would occasionally strike, causing his music player to stop working. He says he "truly hit a wall" on Christmas Eve, where "everything was just saying 'no more, not one more step.'" But he devoured some dried meat, juice, and chocolate and pushed through, even hanging up his stinky socks as "makeshift stockings" for Santa that night. Sears' message from Andy Murray's mom once he arrived at his destination: "Well done Scott Sears." If Guinness confirms Sears' feat, he'll be three years younger than the previous record-holder, per the Telegraph. (Prince Harry drank champagne out of a prosthetic leg when he arrived at the South Pole.)

He should be considered armed and dangerous, and anyone who comes into contact with him is advised to contact law enforcement immediately.

In Other Words, a feminist bookstore in Portland, Oregon, has severed ties with the popular TV show Portlandia, which for six seasons used the store as a filming location for the fictional bookstore Women and Women First. The decision to discontinue the relationship with Portlandia was made in response to a series of issues, including the show's portrayal of transgender individuals, lack of diversity, and the negative impact on the local community.

The bookstore's management claims that Portlandia left their space in a mess, mistreated their staff, forced neighboring businesses to close without warning, and the small fee they received did not cover the losses incurred during filming. The show's portrayal of transgender individuals, specifically a joke involving Fred Armisen in a dress, was criticized as trans-antagonistic, trans-misogynist, and offensive.

Furthermore, the lack of diversity on Portlandia, particularly the absence of Black characters, was noted as problematic, given that In Other Words is located in a historically Black neighborhood in Portland and has a strong connection with the Black Lives Matter movement. The show's portrayal of gentrification was also criticized for trivializing the issue of mass displacement in Portland.

The current management of In Other Words, including the board, staff, and volunteers, were not involved in the initial decision to allow Portlandia to film at the store. They stand by their decision to discontinue the relationship with the show and have expressed their support for the "Fuck Portlandia" sign that was placed in the store's window.

The bookstore is seeking donations and volunteers to continue serving as a hub for Portland's social justice community. They invite those interested in supporting their stance or volunteering to contact them at scheduling@inotherwords.org.
answers: Portland's In Other Words bookstore is well known to Portlandia fans as the fictional Women and Women First bookstore featured in sketches on the show—but it's safe to say ties have been severed between the bookstore and the show, considering a sign that appears on the bookstore's door reading, "Fuck Portlandia! Transmisogyny – Racism – Gentrification – Queer Antagonism – Devaluation of Feminist Discourse." The Willamette Week tried on Tuesday to get an explanation from the bookstore, and a representative at first offered an interview, but also asked (repeatedly) for the Week to post a link to an online fundraiser the bookstore is running. After the Week declined to guarantee a link would be posted (though one did, in fact, end up getting posted in the ensuing article), the bookstore took back its offer of an interview in no uncertain terms. "After some consideration and research we've decided to officially tell the Willamette Weekly to go fuck themselves," read a message from the rep. "Your paper has absolutely zero journalistic professionalism and you are scummy rape apologists. Thanks for the opportunity tho! Have a great night." Then, Wednesday, a blog post went up on the bookstore's website explaining the "Fuck Portlandia" sign. It was placed on the window, and the store's relationship with the show was formally discontinued, as "a direct response to a particular egregious filming of the show in our space which saw our store left a mess, our staff mistreated, our neighbors forced to close and lose business for a day without warning, and our repeated attempts to obtain accountability or resolution dismissed," the blog post reads. "It was also a direct response to a show which is in every way diametrically opposed to our politics and the vision of society we’re organizing to realize. A show which has had a net negative effect on our neighborhood and the city of Portland as a whole." There's a lot more where that came from, here.

Two former Nazi SS guards, aged 93 and 92, have been indicted by German prosecutors for their roles as accessories to murder while serving at the Stutthof concentration camp during World War II. The camp, located near the Polish city of Gdansk, is estimated to have resulted in the deaths of approximately 65,000 prisoners, including Jews, Poles, and Soviet prisoners of war. The defendants, who have not been named, served as guards and watched over prisoners who were forced to work outside the camp.

The indictments were filed last week at the state court in Muenster but were only announced this week. Both men deny any knowledge of the killings at the camp. However, German prosecutors argue that the defendants were aware of the various killing methods used in the camp and willingly supported several hundreds of inmates' killings in their function as guards.

Judith Meisel, an 88-year-old Holocaust survivor from St. Louis Park, has been identified as a key witness in the case. She survived the Stutthof concentration camp and has provided crucial details about the camp's atrocities to German authorities. Meisel identified one of the defendants, Johann Rehbogen, as a teenage SS officer who taunted prisoners, including Meisel, as they undressed each morning.

German prosecutors have been pursuing cases against former Nazis since 2011, using new legal reasoning that allows the prosecution of former Nazis who can't be tied to specific killings but can be linked to the operation of concentration camps. The trial for Rehbogen and Harry Paul Fritz Schulz, the other defendant, is expected to commence next summer if they are deemed healthy enough.

Meisel's involvement in the case has brought back painful memories, including witnessing camp inmates killed by injections and being forced on a death march with her sister, who also escaped. Despite the emotional toll, Meisel welcomes the opportunity to seek justice for her mother and to continue sharing her story for the important lessons it teaches about tolerance and racism.
answers: Judith Meisel says that when she was a teenager in the Stutthof concentration camp in western Poland, other prisoners told her: "Don't let us die without you mentioning what happened to us." The 88-year-old Minnesota resident has not forgotten: Her testimony helped German authorities indict two former guards from the camp where 65,000 people, including Meisel's mother, died, the Minneapolis Star Tribune reports. They deny any knowledge of killings at the camp, where thousands were starved to death or froze. Prosecutors say prisoners were also gassed to death, shot, and killed with lethal injections. Authorities say Meisel and several other Stutthof survivors in the US could be called as witnesses if the former guards are deemed healthy enough to stand trial. The West Coast marine ecosystem is facing a severe decline in the population of Pacific sardines, a crucial forage fish that serves as a primary food source for various species, including seabirds, whales, sharks, dolphins, and commercially important fish like salmon and tuna. The Pacific Fishery Management Council (PFMC) is urged to take action to protect the ecosystem by setting conservative catch limits for sardines and prohibiting unregulated fishing on other forage fish species such as sand lance, saury, and lanternfish. The decline in sardine population is a cause for concern, with the November 2013 population estimate being the lowest in more than a decade, far below the peak of 1.5 million tons estimated in 2000.

The sardine fishing boat Eileen, in a reflection of the current situation, returned to port without a catch after 12 hours and $1,000 worth of fuel. The steep decline in sardine population is attributed to the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, a naturally occurring climate cycle that has brought cold, nutrient-rich water to the West Coast. However, the exact cause of the decline is unclear, and the crash is raising alarm among experts.

If sardines do not recover soon, the marine mammals, seabirds, and fishermen of the West Coast could suffer for years. Some experts argue that continuing to fish for sardines could speed their decline and arrest any recovery. The Pacific sardine is known for its boom-bust cycles, with numbers wildly unpredictable and surging up and down in decades-long cycles in response to natural shifts in the ocean environment.

Researchers are debating the extent to which ocean conditions and overfishing have contributed to the current decline. They also suggest that the scarcity of prey, particularly fatty sardines, could be the leading cause of the 1,600 malnourished sea lion pups that washed up along beaches from Santa Barbara to San Diego in early 2013.

For further information and to voice concerns, individuals are encouraged to visit pewenvironment.org/pacificfish and write to the Pacific Fishery Management Council at pfmc.comments@noaa.gov.
answers: The West Coast sardine population was down 72% since 2006 per a fall assessment—the worst crash since the mid-20th century, and one with far-reaching implications, particularly since the steep decline is expected to continue. One of those implications: Ocean predators that depend on sardines may be starving, the Los Angeles Times reports: Researchers think 1,600 malnourished sea lion pups that washed up onshore in Southern California last year were born to nursing mothers whose milk quality was compromised after they had to turn from fatty sardines to other fish; brown pelicans—which also depend on sardines for food—are also suffering. Neither species can turn to anchovies as an alternative food source, as they normally would, because their numbers are also down. Fishermen, too, are affected; they're not allowed to catch as many sardines (harvest maximums have been dramatically cut)—and they often can't find any to catch (the LA Times follows one boat that caught zero fish in a 12-hour outing). So what's going on? Sardine populations often experience wild swings, booming when conditions are good and then dropping sharply when conditions shift. After the last bad collapse, which happened after a massive boom in the 1940s, sardine fishing was halted for 18 years beginning in the 1960s, and though the population bounced back in the 1980s, it was never the same. Scientists now, as then, aren't sure how to divide the blame between ocean conditions (the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, a climate cycle, has brought cold, sardine-unfriendly water to the area) and overfishing. Last month, Pew Charitable Trusts warned that dozens of species, including whales, sharks, dolphins, salmon, and tuna, could feel an impact.

This news serves as a reminder of the ongoing efforts to preserve the internet's history, while the controversy surrounding "Get Hard" highlights the ongoing debate about representation and stereotypes in mainstream media.

In the end, the success of "Get Hard" at the box office and the long-term impact of its controversial content remains to be seen. Meanwhile, the Internet Archive continues to receive valuable data donations from Alexa Internet, contributing to the preservation of the internet's history.

With accusations that Get Hard is homophobic and racist, Ferrell defends the flick to the AP, noting he and costar Kevin Hart "show a mirror to what's already existing out there." Do critics agree? "Perhaps there's an edgy dark comedy to be made about race, class, and the prospect of facing prison, but Get Hard is not it," Claudia Puig writes at USA Today. The film's "jokes are a cavalcade of racist and homophobic humorlessness." And though its cracks at class divisions perform better, they aren't worth the price of a movie ticket. Her advice: "Unless you're really hard up for entertainment, stay away from this tone-deaf raunchfest." It "seeks to make you laugh while also risking offense by going too far. He says in its original location near a pub, the devices could have caused carnage. "If that pub was crowded and there was a lot of people there, it could have severely injured, killed and maimed many, many people," the mayor says. The AP reports that thousands of Amtrak and NJ Transit passengers were affected by the discovery of the device, with some stuck on trains for hours. Service has resumed but passengers in the area have been warned that they can expect delays Monday. NBC New York reports that investigators believe surveillance video shows the same man at two locations where explosive devices were found in Manhattan. Police aren't sure whether there is a link between the New York devices and those found in New Jersey. CNN reports that there is now an increased security presence in New York City not just because of the bombs, but because world leaders are gathering for the United Nations General Assembly. A law enforcement source tells CBS that investigators believe cell phones were used as triggers for both the Manhattan blast—which NY Gov. Andrew Cuomo calls "obviously an act of terrorism"—and the device that exploded before a New Jersey race to benefit Marines and sailors early Saturday. It's not clear whether a trigger was found with the Elizabeth devices. Bollwage says he's not sure his city was targeted. He suspects somebody may have just dumped the devices in Elizabeth, but he is "extremely concerned for everyone in the state and country where someone can just go and drop a backpack into a garbage can that has multiple explosives in it with no timers and then you have to wonder how many people could have been hurt." An official close to the investigation tells Reuters that all the devices involved have been crude and the level of planning appears low—but some investigators fear this was just a test. "That's what worries us," he says. "Was this some kind of test run, not just of the devices, but also of the surveillance in New York and the response?" (The FBI says it is questioning five people found in a "vehicle of interest.")

The first outbreak occurred in Germany and Yugoslavia in 1967, with 31 reported cases and 7 deaths. Another outbreak occurred in South Africa in 1975, resulting in 1 death and the infection of two others. In 1980, a case was reported in Kenya, followed by another in 1987. The researchers begin their study by noting just how prevalent potato consumption is, with 35% of American women ages 19-50 eating potatoes daily, and the vegetable accounting for 8% of their caloric intake. answers: Thanks to a team of researchers from Belgium, we may be close to synthesizing and, yes, possibly even bottling and selling the smell of human death, Discovery reports. Eva Cuypers and her team at the University of Leuven separated the tissues and organs of six humans and 26 different animals, placing them in jars to decompose over the next six months. Cuypers and her team published their findings last week. They believe the results could be used to better train cadaver dogs or even create a machine that could do the same job. And Discovery points out the synthetic smell of decomposing human bodies could prove popular at Halloween parties. Experts have questioned components of the research—including the separation of tissue and organs—and Cuypers plans a follow-up study using full bodies buried in a field, Science reports. The first report, published in the journal Nature, indicates that Antarctica is shedding ice at a rate of approximately 200 billion tonnes per year, a three-fold increase since 2012. This ice loss is causing global sea levels to rise by 0.6mm annually, with West Antarctica and the Antarctic Peninsula experiencing the most significant losses. The losses in West Antarctica have climbed from 53 billion to 159 billion tonnes per year, while the Antarctic Peninsula has seen an increase from seven billion to 33 billion tonnes annually. East Antarctica, the largest part of the continent, is the only region showing some growth, but it is minimal, running at about five billion tonnes per year.

The second report, released by an international team of ice experts, states that Antarctica has lost about 3 trillion tonnes of ice since 1992, with the southern-most continent's ice sheet melting enough to cover Texas to a depth of nearly 13 feet (4 meters). This melting has caused global oceans to rise by three-tenths of an inch (7.6 millimeters). The study, which includes 88 co-authors, used 10 to 15 satellites, ground and air measurements, and computer simulations to analyze ice loss in 24 different ways.

The third report, also published in Nature, suggests that the East Antarctic ice sheet did not retreat significantly 2 million to 5 million years ago, even when heat-trapping carbon dioxide levels were similar to what they are now. This finding contradicts the idea that East Antarctica might be unstable in a warming climate.

These reports highlight the urgent need for governments to take account of the accelerating ice loss in Antarctica when planning future defenses for low-lying coastal communities. The researchers emphasize that the losses are primarily due to warmer ocean waters, which are causing the floating edges of ice sheets to melt from below. The scientists also stress that the losses are not natural and are likely a result of climate change.
answers: Scientists monitoring ice loss in Antarctica have chilling news: The melting rate has accelerated alarmingly and the ice sheet is now shedding more than 200 billion tons a year, according to a study involving 88 scientists published in the journal Nature. The researchers say the rate of ice loss has tripled over the last decade and the melting ice sheets are now pushing up sea levels around the world by around a half-millimeter every year, reports the BBC. Antarctica was losing around 49 billion tons of ice a year in the mid-1990s, which went up to an average 219 billion tons a year between 2012 and 2017, the study found. The researchers, who used satellite data going back more than 25 years, say most of the melting ice comes from the West Antarctic sheet, parts of which are in a "state of collapse"—and modest ice growth in the East Antarctic is nowhere near enough to offset it. "The increasing mass loss that they’re finding is really worrying, particularly looking at the West Antarctic, the area that’s changing most rapidly," University of Waterloo glaciologist Christine Dow tells the Washington Post. "And it’s the area that we’re most worried about, because it’s below sea level." Antarctica has lost a total of around 3 trillion tons of ice since 1992 and will be contributing more and more to sea level rise if the current trend continues, warn researchers, who say climate change is the only plausible explanation for the ice loss. "I think we should be worried. That doesn't mean we should be desperate," says study co-author Isabella Velicogna of the University of California Irvine, per the AP. "Things are happening. They are happening faster than we expected."

The article also mentions the growing number of climbers on Everest and the difficulty in managing its popularity while ensuring safety in the increasingly dangerous high-altitude environment.

Passage 2 focuses on the risks faced by Sherpas working on Everest and compares their fatality rate to that of other dangerous professions such as commercial fishing, wilderness aviation, military combat, and U.S. military personnel in Iraq. The article uses the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics' formula for fatality rates per 100,000 full-time equivalents to make the comparison. The results show that the fatality rate for Sherpas on Everest is significantly higher than the death rate for U.S. military personnel in Iraq from 2003 to 2007. The article also notes that the number of Sherpas killed on Everest has been rising since 2010, with 17 deaths in 2014 alone.

In summary, the news highlights the ongoing challenges and dilemmas on Mount Everest, including overcrowding, unstable conditions, and the high fatality rate among Sherpas. The articles also discuss the decision by Russell Brice to cancel his climb due to the dangerous conditions and the high risks faced by Sherpas working on the mountain. The comparison of the fatality rate for Sherpas on Everest to that of other dangerous professions underscores the extreme risks faced by these workers.
answers: Jon Krakauer takes to the pages of the New Yorker to weigh in on the latest tragedy on Everest (the author was, of course, part of the 1996 disaster that saw eight climbers killed). His piece makes plain the imbalance between the dangers faced by Sherpas and the climbers they shepherd to the mountain's peak, but before arriving at that point, he shares a fascinating backstory: That of Himex, a New Zealand-based company that Krakauer calls the most "lucrative commercial guiding operation" on Everest—one that on May 7, 2012, packed up shop after 18 years on the mountain and headed home, taking its guides, members (aka paying climbers, who didn't see their $60,000 refunded), and Sherpas with them. The much-assailed decision was one made by owner Russell Brice, who had grown fearful of a 900-foot-wide overhang of glacial ice set directly above the main route on the mountain's Nepal side, an overhang that his members were directly under for as long as an hour while traversing the route. As Krakauer writes, the "wedge of ice the size of a Beverly Hills mansion" that broke free and caused last week's avalanche came from "that same ice bulge" and killed 16 Sherpas. As for the outsize dangers Sherpas face, some standout points: Between 1921 and 1996, the mountain's death ratio was a treacherous one death for every four completed ascents. Between 1997 and present, the death ratio was one for every 60. Among the reasons it's gotten safer: Climbers tend to pack and use more bottled oxygen, and some take the robust steroid dexamethasone once they hit 22,000 feet, which pares down the risk of developing the often fatal high-altitude cerebral edema and high-altitude pulmonary edema. Sherpas typically have less of the former and none of the latter (and are, of course, the ones lugging those extra oxygen bottles up the mountain). Krakauer points to an Outside piece that shares the professions with a lower calculated fatality rate than that of Sherpas: US soldiers stationed in Iraq between 2003 and 2007, miners, and commercial fishermen.

New Horizons will keep traveling into the Kuiper Belt debris field and beyond after it passes Pluto, National Geographic notes, and it may have more research to do if NASA approves funding. (The astronomer who first spotted Pluto in 1930 is the spacecraft's only passenger.)
